}} In medicine (pulmonology), 'psittacosis' â also known as 'parrot disease',
'parrot fever', and 'ornithosis' â is a zoonotic infectious disease caused by a
bacterium called [[Chlamydophila psittaci]] (formerly [[Chlamydia psittaci]])
and contracted from parrots, such as macaws, cockatiels and budgerigars, and
pigeons, sparrows, ducks, hens, gulls and many other species of bird. The
incidence of infection in canaries and finches is believed to be lower than in
psittacine birds.

In certain contexts, the word "psittacosis" is used when the disease is carried
by any species of bird belonging to the Psittacidae family, whereas "ornithosis"
is used when other birds carry the disease.
